w:r.w:t: The Live API is in preview.

The Live API enables low-latency, real-time voice and video interactions with Gemini. It processes continuous streams of audio, video, or text to deliver immediate, human-like spoken responses, creating a natural conversational experience for your users.
Live API offers a comprehensive set of features such as
This page gets you up and running with examples and basic code samples.
Check out the following example applications that illustrate how to use Live API for end-to-end use cases:
on AI Studio, using JavaScript libraries to connect to Live API and stream bidirectional audio through your microphone and speakers.
using Pyaudio that connects to Live API.
If you prefer a simpler development process, you can use
. These are third-party partner platforms that have already integrated the Gemini Live API over the WebRTC protocol to streamline the development of real-time audio and video applications.
There are two important decisions to make before you begin building with the Live API: choosing a model and choosing an implementation approach.
If you're building an audio-based use case, your choice of model determines the audio generation architecture used to create the audio response:
This option provides the most natural and realistic-sounding speech and better multilingual performance. It also enables advanced features like
(where the model can decide to ignore or respond to certain inputs), and
. Native audio is supported by the following
model, uses a cascaded model architecture (native audio input and text-to-speech output). It offers better performance and reliability in production environments, especially with
When integrating with Live API, you'll need to choose one of the following implementation approaches:
: Your backend connects to the Live API using
. Typically, your client sends stream data (audio, video, text) to your server, which then forwards it to the Live API.
: Your frontend code connects directly to the Live API using
to stream data, bypassing your backend.

Client-to-server generally offers better performance for streaming audio and video, since it bypasses the need to send the stream to your backend first. It's also easier to set up since you don't need to implement a proxy that sends data from your client to your server and then your server to the API. However, for production environments, in order to mitigate security risks, we recommend using
, sends it in the correct format, and saves the received data as WAV file.
You can send audio by converting it to 16-bit PCM, 16kHz, mono format, and you can receive audio by setting
as response modality. The output uses a sample rate of 24kHz.
import pkg from 'wavefile'; // npm install wavefile
// WARNING: Do not use API keys in client-side (browser based) applications
systemInstruction: "You are a helpful assistant and answer in a friendly tone."
// Ensure audio conforms to API requirements (16-bit PCM, 16kHz, mono)
// If already in correct format, you can use this:
// Combine audio data strings and save as wave file
const intArray = new Int16Array(buffer.buffer, buffer.byteOffset, buffer.byteLength / Int16Array.BYTES_PER_ELEMENT);
guide for key capabilities and configurations; including Voice Activity Detection and native audio features.
guide to learn how to integrate Live API with tools and function calling.
guide for managing long running conversations.

The Live API is in preview.
This is a comprehensive guide that covers capabilities and configurations available with the Live API. See
page for a overview and sample code for common use cases.
If you haven't already done so, read the
page first. This will introduce you to the fundamental principles of the Live API, how it works, and the distinction between the
and their corresponding audio generation methods (
Try the Live API in AI Studio:
You may find it useful to try the Live API in
before you start building. To use the Live API in Google AI Studio, select
The following example shows how to create a connection with an API key:
field. This means that you can configure the model to respond with either text or audio, but not both in the same session.
The following sections provide examples and supporting context for the different input and output modalities available in Live API.
Here's how you can send and receive text:
Use incremental updates to send text input, establish session context, or restore session context. For short contexts you can send turn-by-turn interactions to represent the exact sequence of events:
inputTurns = [{ "role": "user", "parts": [{ "text": "What is the capital of Germany?" }] }]
For longer contexts it's recommended to provide a single message summary to free up the context window for subsequent interactions. See
for another method for loading session context.
example that reads a WAV file, sends it in the correct format and receives text output:
// Install helpers for converting files: npm install wavefile
// Ensure audio conforms to API requirements (16-bit PCM, 16kHz, mono)
// If already in correct format, you can use this:
example. You can receive audio by setting
as response modality. This example saves the received data as WAV file:
// Combine audio data strings and save as wave file
const intArray = new Int16Array(buffer.buffer, buffer.byteOffset, buffer.byteLength / Int16Array.BYTES_PER_ELEMENT);

Audio data in the Live API is always raw, little-endian, 16-bit PCM. Audio output always uses a sample rate of 24kHz. Input audio is natively 16kHz, but the Live API will resample if needed so any sample rate can be sent. To convey the sample rate of input audio, set the MIME type of each audio-containing
You can enable transcription of the model's audio output by sending
in the setup config. The transcription language is inferred from the model's response.
You can enable transcription of the audio input by sending
// Ensure audio conforms to API requirements (16-bit PCM, 16kHz, mono)
// If already in correct format, you can use this:
To see an example of how to use the Live API in a streaming audio and video format, run the "Live API - Get Started" file in the cookbooks repository:
The Live API models each support a different set of voices. Half-cascade supports Puck, Charon, Kore, Fenrir, Aoede, Leda, Orus, and Zephyr. Native audio supports a much longer list (identical to
). You can listen to all the voices in
To specify a voice, set the voice name within the
object as part of the session configuration:
API, the set of available voices is slightly different. See the
To change the language, set the language code within the
object as part of the session configuration:
models automatically choose the appropriate language and don't support explicitly setting the language code.
The following capabilities are only available with native audio. You can learn more about native audio in
Choose a model and audio generation
Native audio models currently have limited tool use support. See
How to use native audio output
To use native audio output, configure one of the
// Send audio input and receive audio
This feature lets Gemini adapt its response style to the input expression and tone.
To use affective dialog, set the api version to
const ai = new GoogleGenAI({ apiKey: "GOOGLE_API_KEY", httpOptions: {"apiVersion": "v1alpha"} });
Note that affective dialog is currently only supported by the native audio output models.
When this feature is enabled, Gemini can proactively decide not to respond if the content is not relevant.
To use it, set the api version to
field in the setup message and set
const ai = new GoogleGenAI({ apiKey: "GOOGLE_API_KEY", httpOptions: {"apiVersion": "v1alpha"} });
Note that proactive audio is currently only supported by the native audio output models.
// Send audio input and receive audio
Voice Activity Detection (VAD) allows the model to recognize when a person is speaking. This is essential for creating natural conversations, as it allows a user to interrupt the model at any time.
When VAD detects an interruption, the ongoing generation is canceled and discarded. Only the information already sent to the client is retained in the session history. The server then sends a
The Gemini server then discards any pending function calls and sends a
message with the IDs of the canceled calls.
// If realtime playback is implemented in your application,
// you should stop playing audio and clear queued playback here.
By default, the model automatically performs VAD on a continuous audio input stream. VAD can be configured with the
When the audio stream is paused for more than a second (for example, because the user switched off the microphone), an
event should be sent to flush any cached audio. The client can resume sending audio data at any time.
, the API will respond to audio automatically based on VAD. While
adds messages to the model context in order,
is optimized for responsiveness at the expense of deterministic ordering.
For more control over the VAD activity, you can configure the following parameters. See
import { GoogleGenAI, Modality, StartSensitivity, EndSensitivity } from '@google/genai';
Alternatively, the automatic VAD can be disabled by setting
in the setup message. In this configuration the client is responsible for detecting user speech and sending
messages at the appropriate times. An
isn't sent in this configuration. Instead, any interruption of the stream is marked by an
You can find the total number of consumed tokens in the
field of the returned server message.
console.debug('Used %s tokens in total. Response token breakdown:\n', turn.usageMetadata.totalTokenCount);
You can specify the media resolution for the input media by setting the
field as part of the session configuration:
Consider the following limitations of the Live API when you plan your project.
You can only set one response modality (

) per session in the session configuration. Setting both results in a config error message. This means that you can configure the model to respond with either text or audio, but not both in the same session.
The Live API only provides server-to-server authentication by default. If you're implementing your Live API application using a
Audio-only sessions are limited to 15 minutes, and audio plus video sessions are limited to 2 minutes. However, you can configure different
for unlimited extensions on session duration.
A session has a context window limit of:
32k tokens for other Live API models
Live API supports the following languages.
models automatically choose the appropriate language and don't support explicitly setting the language code.
guides for essential information on using the Live API effectively.
For more info about the Live API models, see

Tool use allows Live API to go beyond just conversation by enabling it to perform actions in the real-world and pull in external context while maintaining a real time connection. You can define tools such as
Here's a brief overview of the available tools for each model:

Live API supports function calling, just like regular content generation requests. Function calling lets the Live API interact with external data and programs, greatly increasing what your applications can accomplish.
You can define function declarations as part of the session configuration. After receiving tool calls, the client should respond with a list of
API, the Live API doesn't support automatic tool response handling. You must handle tool responses manually in your client code.
const inputTurns = 'Turn on the lights please';
response: { result: "ok" } // simple, hard-coded function response
From a single prompt, the model can generate multiple function calls and the code necessary to chain their outputs. This code executes in a sandbox environment, generating subsequent
Asynchronous function calling is only supported in

Function calling executes sequentially by default, meaning execution pauses until the results of each function call are available. This ensures sequential processing, which means you won't be able to continue interacting with the model while the functions are being run.
If you don't want to block the conversation, you can tell the model to run the functions asynchronously. To do so, you first need to add a
ensures the function runs asynchronously while you can continue interacting with the model.
Then you need to tell the model how to behave when it receives the
Interrupt what it's doing and tell you about the response it got right away (
Wait until it's finished with what it's currently doing (
Or do nothing and use that knowledge later on in the discussion (
import { GoogleGenAI, Modality, Behavior, FunctionResponseScheduling } from '@google/genai';
// for a non-blocking function definition, apply scheduling in the function response:
scheduling: FunctionResponseScheduling.INTERRUPT // Can also be WHEN_IDLE or SILENT
You can define code execution as part of the session configuration. This lets the Live API generate and execute Python code and dynamically perform computations to benefit your results. See the
const inputTurns = 'Compute the largest prime palindrome under 100000.';
You can enable Grounding with Google Search as part of the session configuration. This increases the Live API's accuracy and prevents hallucinations. See the
const inputTurns = 'When did the last Brazil vs. Argentina soccer match happen?';
You can combine multiple tools within the Live API, increasing your application's capabilities even more:
const prompt = `Hey, I need you to do three things for me.
1. Compute the largest prime palindrome under 100000.
2. Then use Google Search to look up information about the largest earthquake in California the week of Dec 5 2024?
Check out more examples of using tools with the Live API in the
Get the full story on features and configurations from the
In the Live API, a session refers to a persistent connection where input and output are streamed continuously over the same connection (read more about

). This unique session design enables low latency and supports unique features, but can also introduce challenges, like session time limits, and early termination. This guide covers strategies for overcoming the session management challenges that can arise when using the Live API.

Without compression, audio-only sessions are limited to 15 minutes, and audio-video sessions are limited to 2 minutes. Exceeding these limits will terminate the session (and therefore, the connection), but you can use
to extend sessions to an unlimited amount of time.

The lifetime of a connection is limited as well, to around 10 minutes. When the connection terminates, the session terminates as well. In this case, you can configure a single session to stay active over multiple connections using
before the connection ends, allowing you to take further actions.
To enable longer sessions, and avoid abrupt connection termination, you can enable context window compression by setting the
field as part of the session configuration.
To prevent session termination when the server periodically resets the WebSocket connection, configure the
Passing this configuration causes the server to send
messages, which can be used to resume the session by passing the last resumption token as the
console.debug('Connecting to the service with handle %s...', previousSessionHandle)
// The handle of the session to resume is passed here, or else null to start a new session.
// ...Store newHandle and start new session with this handle here
Receiving a message before the session disconnects
message that signals that the current connection will soon be terminated. This message includes the
, indicating the remaining time and lets you take further action before the connection will be terminated as ABORTED.
Receiving a message when the generation is complete
message that signals that the model finished generating the response.
Explore more ways to work with the Live API in the full
Ephemeral tokens are short-lived authentication tokens for accessing the Gemini API through
. They are designed to enhance security when you are connecting directly from a user's device to the API (a

implementation). Like standard API keys, ephemeral tokens can be extracted from client-side applications such as web browsers or mobile apps. But because ephemeral tokens expire quickly and can be restricted, they significantly reduce the security risks in a production environment.
Ephemeral tokens are only compatible with
at this time. You should use them when accessing the Live API directly from client-side applications to enhance API key security.
Here's how ephemeral tokens work at a high level:
Your client (e.g. web app) authenticates with your backend.
Your backend requests an ephemeral token from Gemini API's provisioning service.
Gemini API issues a short-lived token.
Your backend sends the token to the client for WebSocket connections to Live API. You can do this by swapping your API key with an ephemeral token.
The client then uses the token as if it were an API key.

This enhances security because even if extracted, the token is short-lived, unlike a long-lived API key deployed client-side. Since the client sends data directly to Gemini, this also improves latency and avoids your backends needing to proxy the real time data.
Here is a simplified example of how to get an ephemeral token from Gemini. By default, you'll have 1 minute to start new Live API sessions using the token from this request (
), and 30 minutes to send messages over that connection (
newSessionExpireTime: new Date(Date.now() + (1 * 60 * 1000)), // Default 1 minute in the future
value constraints, defaults, and other field specs, see the
to reconnect the call every 10 minutes (this can be done with the same token even if
It's also possible to lock an ephemeral token to a set of configurations. This might be useful to further improve security of your application and keep your system instructions on the server side.
// You'll need to pass the value under token.name back to your client to use it
You can also lock a subset of fields, see the
Connect to Live API with an ephemeral token
Here's an example that connects to Live API through an ephemeral token. Note that use of ephemeral tokens only adds value when deploying applications that follow
// Use the token generated in the "Create an ephemeral token" section here
const ai = new GoogleGenAI({ apiKey: token.name });
If not using the SDK, note that ephemeral tokens must either be passed in an
query parameter, or in an HTTP
Set a short expiration duration using the
Tokens expire, requiring re-initiation of the provisioning process.
Verify secure authentication for your own backend. Ephemeral tokens will only be as secure as your backend authentication method.
Generally, avoid using ephemeral tokens for backend-to-Gemini connections, as this path is typically considered secure.
Ephemeral tokens are only compatible with
on ephemeral tokens for more information.
